item.title: Cheaper DS3 Connections
item.description:
Your business needs more bandwidth, but the price of a DS3 connection might seem daunting. While upgrading from a T1 line to a DS3 might have seemed expensive in the past, prices have gone down. Even with the current economic climate, a DS3 connection could now be within your budget. DS3, or Data Service level 3, is a digital telecommunications standard initially designed for telephone systems. It’s part of the T-Carrier system and works seamlessly with SONET fiber optic networks...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/cheaper-ds3-connections/

item.title: WAN Network Connections From Copper to Fiber
item.description:
By: John Shepler As the demand for more bandwidth increases, so do LAN, MAN, and WAN speeds. This puts pressure on both copper and fiber-based telecommunication networks to upgrade their speeds more frequently. Let’s examine the options for both traditional TDM (Time Division Multiplexing) and IP (Internet Protocol) networks. Traditional Copper Telecom Lines Copper wiring has been the foundation of electronic communication since the telegraph and telephone networks. While the telegraph is obsolete, the telephone is transitioning technologically, with voice becoming a converged network service...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/wan-network-connections-from-copper-to-fiber/

item.title: 100 Mbps Business Ethernet vs OC3 SONET Bandwidth
item.description:
By: John Shepler Many tech companies and large corporations adopted fiber optic bandwidth service, specifically OC3 SONET, years ago. While some have upgraded to faster SONET options, others have continued using their reliable OC3 service. However, the emergence of 100 Mbps and faster Ethernet MAN and WAN bandwidth is challenging SONET’s dominance. Long-time users are exploring alternatives, while new customers are carefully considering their options. SONET (Synchronous Optical NETwork) within the SDH (Synchronous Digital Hierarchy) became the foundation for most metropolitan, wide area, and international networks in recent decades...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/100-mbps-business-ethernet-vs-oc3-sonet-bandwidth/

item.title: When Only T1 Will Do
item.description:
By: John Shepler While gigabit fiber connections are becoming the norm, T1 lines are still a relevant and useful option for bandwidth needs. T1 service remains popular and could be a perfect fit for your requirements, balancing speed and affordability. Why Consider T1 Lines? T1 is a well-established and widely available telecom service. Although Plain Old Telephone Service (POTS) was once the standard, it’s being replaced by VoIP and cloud-based systems in many businesses...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/-when-only-t1-will-do/

item.title: T1 Line Cost At A New Low
item.description:
For many companies, T1 lines have become a standard over time. Larger corporations adopted them early on for dedicated internet access, while smaller businesses often turned to T1 lines after encountering limitations with shared bandwidth services like DSL and Cable. The only drawback to T1 lines was their costâ€”or was it?
](http://www.t1t3today.com/)
If you associate T1 lines with exorbitant prices, your perception might be outdated. Less than ten years ago, a monthly fee of $1,000 for a standard T1 line wasn’t unusual...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/t1-line-cost-at-a-new-low/

item.title: So, What Does ISDN Stand For?
item.description:
If your business uses telephone systems, you’ve likely encountered the term ISDN. This piece explains what ISDN is and how it can benefit your company. ISDN, or Integrated Services Digital Network, is a digital telephone standard initially intended to replace analog lines for both residential and business users. While DSL, cable broadband, and VoIP surpassed ISDN in the residential market with their higher bandwidths and lower costs, ISDN found its niche as a popular trunking service for business PBX telephone systems and a few specialized applications...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/so-what-does-isdn-stand-for/

item.title: DS3 Bandwidth Alternatives
item.description:
DS3 WAN connections are a popular choice for businesses that need more bandwidth than T1 lines offer but aren’t ready for a full OC-3 fiber optic SONET service. However, exploring alternative options might be beneficial due to cost or performance considerations. There are several bandwidth options available today that might be a better fit than your existing DS3 connection. Let’s explore some alternatives. DS3 bridges the gap between copper wireline and fiber optic bandwidth services...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/ds3-bandwidth-alternatives/
